Description.val:
Weapons and combat vehicle improvements in the areas of survivability, lethality, mobility, command and control for the M1A1 tank and Improved Recovery Vehicle (IRV).  Additionally, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) and upgrades address current and future reliability, sustainability, maintainability, and obsolescence issues to ensure mission readiness and effectiveness on the battlefield.

M1A1 MOD KIT: The M1A1 Mod Kit line sustains and improves the technology of the M1A1 tank and Armored Vehicle Launched Bridge (AVLB).  Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support these platforms.  

Assault Bridging Modernization Program: Replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver. This program will establish commonality across the DoD fleet, eliminates obsolescence and diminishing manufacturing sources and materiel shortfall issues, while increasing the operational effectiveness and readiness of the MAGTF.

IRV:  The Improved Recovery Vehicle (also known as the M88A2 Hercules) is the Marine Air-Ground Task Force's heavy lift, recovery, and battlefield maintenance asset.  This line is designed to sustain and improve the technology of the IRV.  Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support the IRV.

Justification.val:
FY18 Base Appropriation Request: $19.778M

FY 2018 M1A1 MOD KIT $15.918M: Active $13.650M; Reserves $2.268M:
Funds supported modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (active and reserve components) to increase capabilities in survivability and lethality, specifically, to procure the Abrams Integrated Display and Targeting System (AIDATS)
which will complete Full Rate Production (FRP). Modifications included Improved Side Armor (ISA), upgrades to the Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel, and transportability modifications to the Track Width Mine Plow (TWMP).

FY 2018 IRV $3.860M: Active $3.620M; Reserves $0.240M:
Funds supported the procurement of modifications kits and associated Systems Technical Support addressing modernization and mitigating obsolescence for the M88A2. Funds also supported modification of tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles such as Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.

FY19 Base Appropriation Request:  $22.904M

FY 2019 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.881: Active $12.580M; Reserves $2.301M: 
These funds support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (active and reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control.  Funds support the procurement of efforts such as, Improved Side Armor (ISA), Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP), and Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM).  ISA is a modification that significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank.  GPSLP is a modification to the tank's fire control system that enables the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle.  TCM supports the procurement of new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded, in order to meet the new capability requirement of a multi-band radio for the M1A1 tank by FY24. 

FY 2019 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.7M:   
These funds support the procurement of 1 Test Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.  

FY 2019 IRV $2.323M: Active $2.112M; Reserves $0.211M: 
These funds support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform.  Additionally, this funding supports modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.

FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $22.760M

FY 2020 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.439: Active $12.641M; Reserves $1.798M: 
These funds continue to support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (active and reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility and command and control.  Funds in support of survivability efforts allow for the procurement of Improved Side Armor (ISA) which significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank.  Funds in support of lethality efforts procure a new Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP).  This modification to the tank's fire control system will enable the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle.  Funds for the command and control effort procure communication systems as part of the Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM) effort.  TCM procures new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded, in order to meet the new capability requirement of a multi-band radio for the M1A1 tank by FY24.  Funds for installation kits support the capabilities efforts of survivability, lethality, and command and control.  These funds procure the cables, mounting hardware, installation material, and labor for the Abrams Integrated Display and Targeting System (AIDATS), ISA, and TCM installation process.  The decrease from FY19 to FY20 is attributed to the reduction in level of effort for Command and Control which consists of Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM).

Starting in FY20 M1A1 MOD KIT reflects various shifts in program funding to better align requirements to the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility and command and control. The increase to Installation Kits is for the inclusion of AIDATS, ISA, TCM, and APS, which will vary annually based on depot level maintenance throughput at LOGCOM. Survivability was added to consolidate APS B-Kits, countermeasures, calibration kits and ISA which fluctuates due to throughput at the depot rebuild line. Lethality increased due to the shift of various upgrades modifications to include the ADL Increment II, the GPSLP in the FEP System, and improved proficiency of the Advances Gunnery Training System in the Tanks. Lethality also includes productions associated costs such as engineering spt., safety spt., and product spt., which were moved from engineering spt. and program management spt. moving forward. 

FY 2020 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.7M:   
These funds support the procurement of 1 Production Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.  

FY 2020 IRV $2.621M: Active $2.406M; Reserves $0.215M: 
These funds will support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform.  Funding increase from FY19 to FY20 of $.298M will support modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.

Name.@footnote: FY19 unit cost adjusted to reflect actual unit price for both active and reserve funding.
In FY20 product support is being consolidated under the production lines (lethality, survivability, communication, mobility)

Increase in FY20 due to the inclusion of AIDATS, ISA, TCM, and APS in the consolidated cost category for installation kits for FY20 and beyond. Installation cost will vary based on throughput at the rebuild line and fielding plan of the operational forces.

Increase in FY20 due to the inclusion of AIDATS, ISA, TCM, and APS in the consolidated cost category for installation kits for FY20 and beyond. Installation will vary annually based on depot level maintenance throughput at LOGCOM.

The increase in FY20 for Lethality consolidates upgrade modifications to the ADL Increment II, the Gunners Primary Sight Lower Panel in the FEP System which is part of the implementation of ADL II, and improves proficiency of the Advanced Gunnery Training System in the Tanks. Also included in this line are costs associated with production items such as engineering spt, safety support, and product support.

Lethality consolidates upgrade modifications to the ADL Increment II, Gunners Primary Sight Lower Panel in the FEP System which is part of the implementation of ADL II, and to improve proficiency of the Advanced Gunnery Training System in the Tanks. Also included in this line are costs associated with production items such as engineering spt, safety support, and product support.
Procured AIDATS and TCSH Cables and Brackets, TWMP Tie Down, Rear View Mirror Sensor, Cables, Driver Viewing Enhancement (DVE) in both active and reserve funding.

Communication Modernization was changed to Command and Control to better align with program description.  Consists of Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM) radio procurement for both active and reserve funding.
Beginning in FY20 Survivability consists of APS B-Kits, countermeasures, calibration kits; and Improved Side Armor to align with the program description.
FY19 procured 1 test article; FY20 procures 1 production article
